Let me start this by saying I really, really enjoy playing DD.  With that said, the new shieldbreaker class has more baggage to it than it brings to the table.

The basic idea of the shieldbreaker is all in the name.  She specializes in dealing with those armored enemies.  In a void, she would be a great character that fit right in, but in the game as it is now, she is a burden not worth the hassle of bringing her along.

A few points I would like to make, they are:  

1. She can do some blight damage, which, with the release of CC, isn't as useful as often as bleed is (I get it, the snake theme...)  The problem with this is the CC expansion itself.  You bring your shieldbreaker into the ruins thinking its a good fit, but once those CC enemies start popping up, you will wonder why you picked any blight skills at all. (Granted, this happens to the PD as well, but PD has far more other tricks)

2. The skills don't see to really make her a better pick than other strong bleed/blighters to take down armored foes.  This serves into the biggest point yet...

3. If you camp with her, she will be in for a world of pain.  It's a 100% fight.  She will get to 100 stress before its over.  You will almost assuredly walk out of camping with a shieldbreaker far, far worse than you did when you camped in the first place.

4. The highwayman seems to have far better abilities that forward 1 and back 1, and even a melee bleed for the armored mobs.  Upon comparing the two, AEGIS looks great on paper, but you have to forgo a round to get it, and it only blocks actual damage, not stress or other non damaging attacks.

To summarize, I enjoyed the lore, the look, and the idea of the shieldbreaker, but the actual execution of this class leaves it in the mud at the wheel of the stage coach.  

I love DD, but sadly, I have mod classes that i'd pay $4 for before the shieldbreaker.

- There are only seven of them. The fourth and fifth only appear in Veteran difficulty at least, and the sixth and seventh won't until Champion difficulty. Which means you're in the clear if you're done with the first three and you want to do a Medium/Long Lvl 1 Mission, for example.
- Your SB will suffer 23 stress for 6 rounds. So using the camping skill Pep Talk a few times, and bringing a stress healer along will pretty much negate it.
- The enemies were made to be countered by the SB's skills. Use Expose on stealthed enemies to kill them extremely fast, use the armor piercing skills (and the armor piercing bonus from the camping skills), just play smart.

Some other reviews mention that this class comes with "baggage". It's true. Her unique "encounters" at night can quickly drive her to insanity. I feel like reviews are too harsh on her and gloss over some details:
1) While her encounters are annoying, they only appear a certain number of times per difficulty. Each time you beat the encounter you get one of her trinkets, and I think this is the only way to get the trinkets.

2) The encounters aren't difficult. The unique enemies in the fight aren't tough or particularly hard hitting, its just a DPS race to prevent the shieldbreaker from going insane. 

3) The shieldbreaker herself is unique and fairly fun to play. She brings a little bit of everything to the table with AOE damage, DOTS, direct damage and a lot of front row self shuffling. A side effect of the shuffling is that she doesn't remain out of position for long if pushed to the back.

4) She brings new mechanics to the table that others don't. While she doesn't deal as much damage as a highwayman or arbalest, she does have the unique ability to penetrate PROT directly AND bypass Guard entirely, even breaking the guard to allow others to follow up. This can dramatically change the tactics of some of the games harder fights.

I want to note that all this is in a week 106ish normal difficulty run, I have not tried her on Radiant or Stygian. Two spoiler tips for the Shieldbreaker: Her horror effect in the nightmare cannot be cleansed by the new supply item for some reason, and when she has a resolve test in the nightmare it is always an affliction. She cannot roll a virtue in it. I don't know if she can't get virtues at all, I haven't had a shieldbreaker have their resolve tested outside the nightmare.

As a class, the Shieldbreaker is great.  She has lots of utility and damage projection, and can literally just block all damage from an incoming attack with one of her abilities.  She's really good in the Endless Mode in CoM.  If you like Darkest Dungeon, get this DLC.  She's an excellent character in that regard.

[h1] BUT [/h1]

On any camping mission, you will get an unavoidable ambush called a nightmare, in which a bunch of really powerful snake enemies attack your party, and the shieldbreaker gets a HUGE stress dot.  If you don't have a party capable of killing the snakes fast enough or a jester, your entire mission will be over.  If you beat it, you get a trinket of varying quality and a story tidbit.
The nightmare ambushes for this class restrict the part building so severely that she's almost zero fun to play.  In short missions she really shines, but everywhere else, she is a huge liability.  They either need to nerf the nightmare somehow, or make it really worth your trouble.  If you hate unfair fights, avoid this one.

A very nice, albeit small DLC to an already great game. The main addition is the new hero class: Shieldbreaker. She's a Middle Eastern themed female warrior. A very nice concept and a great class to use in battle overall with pretty useful skills, with a bit of everything available, whether it's damage dealing, DOT, piercing enemy armour, or gaining a powerful block that neglects all damage to her for a couple of turns. In addition to her abilities, you will also encounter a handful of new enemies associated with her backstory and a droppable loot item that can be very helpful for other heroes.

I am not a big fan of the newly introduced stealth mechanic which makes some enemies untargetable for the first 2 turns unless their stealth is removed via one of the special skills. However, since this update was included into the base game at the time of this DLC's release, you'll be affected by this mechanic either way, so it's better to have an extra class that can deal with stealthy enemies. Aside from the Shieldbreaker, only 5 other hero classes have a skill that can De-Stealth enemies, 3 of which are pretty poor skills that you wouldn't normally equip to a hero that has them anyway. So you'll be very restricted in what classes to bring to the late game dungeons. I personally think it would be nicer if the devs added de-stealth skills to a few more hero classes, so not to restrict the party setup too much.

A pretty small DLC overall, but since it's pretty cheap and since the new hero class is pretty awesome, I'd say it's worth getting, though not necessary to enjoy the base game.

The Shieldbreaker is a DLC for [b]Darkest Dungeon[/b] that adds the Shieldbreaker hero to the game along with some extra stuff.

Straight to the point. Is the Shieldbreaker good? Yes. Very good. So much so that I'd say she's one of the best characters in the game (even considered to be one of the only truly "viable" heroes in a good team composition in The Color of Madness, but that's a story for another review). Hard-hitting abilities that can disable enemies or just shred through their defenses, being able to cause some heavy constant blight damage to one enemy (or even all of them!) while also being able to move through your team composition without ever really finding herself in a "useless" position, I liked this character. Her design is also great, although I believe that her shield is barely used considering she's more focused on dodging than taking on the blows. Character art is great but of course it'd be great. This is Darkest Dungeon after all. Her story was also very interesting to learn about and seeing the dynamic of "broken yet beautiful", having to throw a part of her body "away" so she could truly be free, although I find weird that she thanks her "liberator" but then has nightmares about snakes.

The Shieldbreaker has one big "problem" (or convenience, later on) though, every time you camp with a Shieldbreaker in your team, your team will be automatically ambushed by enemies related to the Shieldbreaker past, while also heavily stressing the SB for every turn while in the camp fight. This is particularly punishing in the early-game, considering that camping is one of the few occasions where you actually feel "safe" to a certain degree in (at least the normal) game and just when you thought everything was good you get instead attacked by these scaly beasts it can really feel annoying. The good thing is that after seven of those lovely encounters every time you camp with the SB she finds comfort in having found... comfort from the demons of her past and gains some nice small buffs. So you basically suffer on the early-game to bet buffs at late-game... which isn't that nice considering that by late-game you barely have anything to worry about with your heroes all tanked up and ready to challenge [b]GOD[/b].

Some short words about the new enemies from this DLC: Pliskin - WILL blight you. Also hard to hit. Rattler - I hate these guys with a passion. Prepare to be slapped back for every slap you do. Adder - Annoying. Will heal, will stun and will laugh at you before being poked. Also! When you defeat all of SB's nightmares you can rarely find them roaming around which is a nice lil thing. Adds some extra diversity to places, although I can see that being annoying to some. They drop the new item though which... can help. Kinda.

The new item added in this DLC is called the Aegis Scale and it is... ok. They work by basically giving you a "total block" for one attack that hits your character. They don't shield against Stress though so they can feel kinda underwhelming, even more so when you use one of them to prepare for a hard-hitting attack and get hit by a weak one. This could be more blamed on the RNG side of the game but still, I wish they at least made you resist 50% of the normal Stress damage you'd receive.

Overall, The Shieldbreaker DLC is a great DLC that, although going the extra mile, just feels underwhelming for what it brings out to the table or just straight up punishing in some occasions.

Good DLC!

I really didn't know where to sit on this one. I feel like the price point is fair, as you get a few new machanics with this character, and she is of high quality and adds a lot to the vanilla roster, but there are too many things bringing it down.

For one, everytime you bring the shieldbreaker with you, you get a sort of special nightmare ambush every single time you camp with her. Yes, every time. There's no way to avoid this, not even character abilities that avoid an ambush at night will stop them. You're forced into a difficult fight each time. Not only this, but she suffers from heavy stress throughout the encounter. There are ways to avoid this, but it's still annoying. The fight itself is with snakes that can dish out both bleed and blight attacks and some have heavy PROT as well for defense. Best yet, because you're guaranteed to fight these snakes each time you bring her, you'll only want to bring her to an area like the Weald or the Warrens, where you'll encounter many beast enemies just so that your party will be prepared for beast type enemies. If you bring her to the Ruins or the Cove, (where she's ironically a strong character as she's able to dish out blight damage, has armor piercing for the high PROT enemies there, and has some attacks that can shut down annoying back row enemies) it's likely that your party won't be prepared for enemies that have high blight resist and count as beast-type enemies. This whole thing would honestly be way better if she had a camping skill that could avoid this, or if you had the option to skip the fight.

The armor piercing and block mechanics are both interesting. Armor piercing thankfully adds yet another way to get around PROT and blocks are a fun way to make your tank characters even more tanky, or make your squishy back row heroes get one free attack to ignore. Guard break is another great idea to add as it provides a way to get around enemies protecting other enemies.

Stealth is meh. Like, really meh. Not many enemies outside of the snakes mentioned above use it, and it's just more of a pest than anything I feel needs to be carefully planned for or taken into consideration.

In the end, it's left to buyer discretion. I would have prefered a third option instead of yes or no. I think I'll enjoy keeping her, but only because a mod recently came out a few days ago that gets rid of the nighttime ambush and adds the snakes to the generic enemy roster, as well as adding the character's trinkets to the existing trinket roster, as the fight itself gets tiring and just makes things too complicated. Not to mention how weird it is that this character gets their own special little event, something no other character gets.

Shieldbreaker is a high damage output frontline class.

She does a lot: 
-High prot piercing damage
-Blight
-Destealth
-Pulling forward
-Guard break
-Buffing herself with the block status (absorbs an attacks damage, not secondary effects like bleed)

She has a unique nightmare mechanic - where after camping it's likely that an ambush-like scenario plays out where you have to fight some unique enemies while she receives a great amount of stress. If you clear all her nightmares, she stops getting them and receives buffs from camping.

There's new provisions - Aegis scales. These function like Shieldbreaker's blocking ability but can be used on any character. They carry over the hamlet if unused and are helpful against dangerous fights.

She's a fun and strong character.

But then she's got unnecessarily overtuned when all she needed were just the flashback tutorials. Another comment has already stated that she just covers everything Hellion and Grave Robber already do.
If you plan to get Color of Madness and Butcher's Circus though, there's absolutely no reason not to get this girl. Might as well be the main reason why this review is still gonna be positive.

The Shieldbreaker's DLC is the smallest by far for Darkest Dungeon, but it brings with it more then simply a new character class.

To understand what she brings to the table, you need to look at what else the DLC brings. Most notably, this DLC introduces a stealth mechanic. Various enemies, such as the Weald witches and the Coves' Pelagic Shaman, can now begin encounters stealthed, which means they cannot be targeted by single-target abilities for several turns. They can still be hit by AoE abilities however, and they can be prematurely revealed by certain hero abilities. Naturally the Shieldbreaker comes with an ability that can do this, but existing characters are now capable of doing so, such as the Arbalest with her Rallying Flare. In addition, the Grave Robber can now stealth herself using her Shadow Fade ability, further adding to her already plentiful bag of dirty tricks.

The Shieldbreaker herself is nothing to sneeze at. In keeping with her backstory as a dancer, her moves heavily rely on shifting her through your party's ranks, and you will likely need to build your party composition around her as a result. For obvious reasons, she partners well with the Grave Robber. The Shieldbreaker is capable of blighting entire enemy formations, ignoring an enemy's PROT and therefore their damage mitigation, exploting Marked enemies, giving herself stacks of Block to ignore attacks outright, and as noted above, bypassing Stealth. Perhaps most importantly, she has the completely unique ability to bypass an enemy's Guarded status and pull them forward in the same action, nullifying the protective abilities of enemies such as the Pelagic Guardian or the Courtyard's Servants.

In exchange for all this, the Shieldbreaker comes with a unique drawback. She is haunted by her past in a far more literal fashion then her fellows. After camping out in a dungeon, there is a 50% chance the SB may be overcome by nightmares of the incident in which she lost her hand, and the party will be attacked by monstrous snake enemies with who variously have nasty Blights, Stealth, Crits and Riposte capability. This battle is of timed duration and inflicts the poor SB with a crippling Horror debuff that cannot be dispelled with Laudanum. If the party fails to defeat the snakes in time they will be inflicted with a nasty stress debuff for the remainder of that quest, the SB recieving a harsher one plus an Accuracy penalty. However, if the snakes are defeated, You will recieve a character-specific trinket for the SB, a unique consumable Scale item that can grant a stack of block to any character, and a big stress buff for the whole party, with the SB receiving a greater one plus a Crit Chance bonus. Defeating all seven of the encounters, each of which has a fixed group of snakes, results in ALL Shieldbreakers you own receiving a unique buff whenever you camp out- She has conquered her fears at last. You will also have collected all her trinkets this way, including her set trinkets.

If you additionally have the Crimson Court DLC, the Shieldbreaker can gain the benefits of the Training Ring District, receiving bonus accuracy and maximum HP.

So, good and bad here.

[b]The second[/b]: The character is fun, and the character herself is aesthetically well-designed. However, I thought the snake motif animations around her skills were a bit heavy-handed, and even a bit garish compared to other characters. Even her default thrust, her spear glows with almost magic light, or when she throws, her javalin becomes a magic poison projectile.... it's a bit blatant for the world. Even the Occultist has a regular knife attack.

[b]The third[/b]: There's a bit too much revealed backstory. All the classes are sort of self-explained trope-characters. We can infer from how they speak, what they reference, how they look like, what the [i]feel[/i] of their backstory is. They don't [i]need[/i] explicit backstories, as if the classes are all [i]literally[/i] a single character. 

In the Shieldbreaker's case, she's missing a hand that she wraps a shield around. How did that happen? Did she escape manacles by cutting her hand off? Did a tyrant remove it as punishment? Was she shielding someone from a blow? Was she a princess? A slave? Does it matter? No, it's all part of the mystique of a character, maybe to be hinted at opaquely in resting dialogue.

Unfortunately, you find journals that tell you [i]explicitly[/i] what happened, and I feel that takes away some of the mystique, some of the sense of them as a [i]class[/i] of character. I thought the trinket flavor text of the Crimson Court managed this well, a sense of discovery, lots to the imagination. 

Lastly, it wasn't immediately clear what motivations she might have to be in the Hamlet, fighting evil, etc. Nor was it clear why she was a "Shieldbreaker" and not a Nomad or Odalisque or Beduin or any number of more atmosophere- and character-consistent alternatives. (And of all characters to have an invulnerability spell... it didn't really feel consistent like the other classes.)

As an experiment with a new class, this DLC is totally fine and fun to mess with. If they do another [i]exactly[/i] like it, I feel it will be a mistep.

And again, all the [i]good[/i] aspects all highlights the possibility for wonderous fun that awaits Darkest Dungeon when they make a sequal or a fresh campaign.

This DLC adds a new class (the Shieldbreaker, obviously - a melee DPS / off-tank), a handful of new enemies, and three new mechanics: Stealth, Armor Piercing, and Guard Break.

The mechanics are all wonderful and (I would argue) should have been a part of the original game. Armor Piercing ignores PROT, making the Shieldbreaker able to directly attack those enemies you used to have to stack Blight and Bleed on. Guard Break allows you to pull a target out of position and remove the Guard status another creature is protecting it with. Stealth prevents monsters (and heroes) from being attacked.

The new enemies are a few snakes (Beasts) that appear scattered lightly throughout the levels. But their main use is as enemies in the Shieldbreaker's Nightmares. Unlike all other heroes, this character will automatically trigger an ambush during camping on Medium or Long missions. The encounters progress through a story-based series of seven chapters, and defeating each one rewards the party with loot and buffs. This makes the hero a real liability in Boss missions.

The Shieldbreaker herself quickly became one of my favorite classes. She has relatively low HP, but features a couple of very strong defensive abilities, and is a master of weaving in and out of different positions in your lineup ("Dancing and fighting - there is no difference", she says). She can bypass every type of enemy defense, hits very hard, and even has a DOT attack (Blight) to boot. This all fits in very well with her snake theme.

Overall I was very pleased with this character and the extras that came with it. I would recommend it to any fan of Darkest Dungone, as the new mechanics make the game better overall, even  if you don't dig the hero herself.

After reading the reviews on steam I decided that I don't want a bunch of cry-baby casuals ruining the review aggregate for my favorite DD class.

Now, I'll preface the whole review by saying that whilst I don't have that many hours on DD in Steam, I can safely assure anybody reading that I have a very deeply mechnical understanding of the way DD is supposed to play, be it through many (shady) playthroughs and watching guides and gameplay.

So now let's actually get into the Shieldbreaker.

Being a DLC that has only one major addition, the price for it is a tad over what it should be. While $4 is nothing spectacular it is a bit too much for a glorified character pack. So right off the bat I can say that It's not a worthwhile buy if it isn't on sale, simply because it doesn't add enough content to make it worthwhile.

The character on the other hand, hoo boy. For starters this class ends up being one of those classes. The ones where putting them in a LV1 dungeon and putting them in a LV6 dungeon is pretty much the same. The abilites the character has are a lot of fun, and they add more movement abilites, which in my personal opinion haven't been explored as much as they should be. Most base game characters only really have movement abilites that are used in situations where they want to move away from a certain rank. Attacks like the Crusader's Holy Lance are just that, since they deal heavily debuffed damage, you'd really only be using it to move forwards. The only classes that do a decent job at moving about are the Highwayman and the Jester, where the Jester is pretty much geared to that sort of playstyle, whilst the Highwayman can pull off the forwards, then backwards manuever pretty well.

The major gripe most people seem to run in with the character is the post-camp encounter. I read a review around here somewhere which explained it better than I could, but in short, the battles are actually preset, so you wouldn't be getting them forever and ever until death do you and her part. Now, the battles themselves. If you hadn't noticed the Shieldbreaker  had also shipped with an ability that no other character had up to that point, that being the De-stealthing mechanic. Characters had the stealth ability far before this, and heck, even some enemies in the Crimson Court used it. But no character had been shipped with an ability that is made for destealthing. That's why the encounter is a tad easier, since you're always going to have a Shieldbreaker for the encounter, you can easiely set her skills up so that she's the most effective against the snakes during the fight. Secondly, even if DD can be quite a bitch when it comes to RNG, this battle might be one of the more balanced ones. Aside from the fact that it's all preset from the word go, it's also a very simple set up, one high-damage/low-hp and 2 high-hp/low-damage enemies at first, then they add another high-damage and then there's a miniboss of sorts. But if you're not an idiot you'd know how many times you'd already fought, so figuring out what battle is next, should be a piece of cake. Provided you have the gamesense for it, that is.

From that rambly wall of text, you should more-or-less get the idea, that for a super fun and fluent character you'd be getting a slight challenge, as if you don't face those every time you play the game to begin with.

$4 for a new hero is a pretty steep price, I'll be perfectly honest. I picked this DLC up on sale, and have played around with it decent amount. So, basically what happens is that you get a new hero class and two new mechanics, stealth (I'm fairly certain this DLC added them in, at least added more stealth enemies in, and aegis.) Aegis is an interesting mechanic, I'll explain how to get this later, but essentially what aegis does is allows you to make one of your heroes ignore all physical damage for 1 round. They way you obtain these, at least early on, is by camping with the SB in your party. This caught me off guard, and almost ruined my boss run, but you encounter a number of snakes after finishing camping, and these are some mean sons of bitches. After killing them, you get a trinket or two, some other assorted loot, and a few scales that are consumables that grant aegis. Its a really useful thing against a few bosses, the prophet namely. The next mechanic is stealth, and this basically serves to make your life more miserable. It makes it so that the enemy who is stealth cannot be targeted for two rounds unless unstealthed. The SB has an unstealth in his kit, and a few other heroes do like the Vestal, but these are pretty precious. The SB also breaks guards, can ignore a portion of protections, and does pretty good damage. All in all its a pretty good DLC, I'd recommend waiting for a sale as $4 for something the fantastic modding community could have made is a little overkill.

Her camping skill that lets your party's attacks ignore 15% of enemy PROT is the (only) reason I was able to beat the Brigand 16 Pounder. Definitely pay-to-win. /sarcasm

But for real, the Shieldbreaker is an odd class to use as all but one of her attacks move her one position forward or backward. For this reason, I generally keep her in the front two ranks, paired with another character who shines in the front two ranks (usually a highwayman or man-at-arms). As the name implies, she's good at bypassing enemy PROT, and has an ability that removes an enemy Guard buff and prevents that enemy from being guarded for a few turns. She can also Blight enemies, de-stealth enemies, and can do an attack that does bonus damage against Marked enemies, making her quite versatile.

Her trinkets are locked behind specific nighttime ambushes that trigger when you have a Shieldbreaker in your party when camping. These cannot be prevented with camping skills, but there are 7 of them in total; after defeating all 7 of them, they will never happen again. After defeating the nighttime ambush, you're awarded with a Shieldbreaker trinket and some other loot.

Overall I think the Shieldbreaker DLC is a fine addition to the game that adds even more depth to party compositions and combat. She works well against enemies weak to Blight and who have PROT (Cove, anyone?), and due to the nature of her moveset and how she moves between ranks, she shrugs at the thought of getting moved or shuffled around in the party by enemies.
